classifications.note: Fundamental law: Στ = Iα, Derived from F = ma for rigid bodies, Valid for fixed axis rotation, Vector form: Στ⃗ = Iα⃗, Net external torque required, Moment of inertia about rotation axis

principles.statement: Rotational Newton's second law establishes fundamental rotational dynamics: Basic Law: Στ = Iα; Net external torque causes angular acceleration; Direct rotational analog of F = ma. Derivation from Particle Systems: Consider rigid body as collection of particles; For each particle: Fᵢ = mᵢaᵢ; Tangential component: Fᵢₜ = mᵢaᵢₜ = mᵢrᵢα; Torque: τᵢ = rᵢFᵢₜ = mᵢrᵢ²α; Sum over all particles: Στ = (Σmᵢrᵢ²)α = Iα. Rigid Body Constraints: All particles have same α; Fixed axis rotation; Internal torques cancel (Newton's third law). Vector Form: Στ⃗ = Iα⃗; Torque and angular acceleration vectors parallel to rotation axis; Right-hand rule determines direction. Physical Interpretation: Net torque is rotational cause; Moment of inertia is rotational resistance; Angular acceleration is rotational effect. Sign Convention: Counterclockwise torque positive; Clockwise torque negative; Consistent with right-hand rule. Limitations: Valid for rigid bodies; Fixed rotation axis; Constant moment of inertia; Net torque about rotation axis. Analogies with Linear Motion: F = ma ↔ τ = Iα; Mass m ↔ Moment of inertia I; Acceleration a ↔ Angular acceleration α; Force F ↔ Torque τ.
principles.application: Apply rotational Newton's second law to dynamics problems. Derive the law from fundamental principles. Analyze vector relationships in rotation. Set up coordinate systems for torque analysis. Solve for unknown quantities using τ = Iα. Verify solutions using multiple methods.
principles.example: Derive τ = Iα from particle dynamics. Analyze direction relationships in rotational motion. Solve for angular acceleration given torque and inertia.
principles.analogy: Like opening a heavy door - the push (torque) you apply determines how quickly the door swings open (angular acceleration), with a heavier door (larger moment of inertia) requiring more push for the same opening speed, exactly as a heavier object requires more force for the same linear acceleration, demonstrating the perfect analogy between F = ma and τ = Iα

worked_examples.title: Rigorous Derivation from Particle Dynamics
worked_examples.problem: Derive Newton's second law for rotation (Στ = Iα) starting from Newton's second law for particles and applying rigid body constraints.

step_by_step.step: Consider rigid body as particle system
step_by_step.explanation: Body consists of N particles with masses mᵢ at positions rᵢ from rotation axis

step_by_step.step: Newton's second law for each particle
step_by_step.explanation: Fᵢ = mᵢaᵢ, where Fᵢ is net force on particle i
Fᵢ = Fᵢᵉˣᵗ + ΣⱼFᵢⱼⁱⁿᵗ, where Fᵢⱼⁱⁿᵗ is force on i from j
Fᵢₜ = mᵢaᵢₜ = mᵢrᵢα (since aₜ = rα for rigid body)
Internal forces occur in action-reaction pairs; τᵢⱼⁱⁿᵗ + τⱼᵢⁱⁿᵗ = 0 (Newton's third law); Internal torques sum to zero
For fixed axis rotation: Στ⃗ = Iα⃗, with τ⃗ and α⃗ parallel to rotation axis

worked_examples.final_answer: Στᵉˣᵗ = Iα; Rigorous derivation from particle dynamics confirms rotational Newton's second law; Internal torques cancel due to Newton's third law, leaving only external torques causing angular acceleration

image.caption: Rigorous derivation of rotational Newton's second law

worked_examples.title: Vector Analysis of Rotational Dynamics
worked_examples.problem: A disk rotates about z-axis with angular acceleration α⃗ = 2k̂ rad/s². A force F⃗ = 3î + 4ĵ N acts at r⃗ = 0.5ĵ m. Verify τ = Iα using vector methods for I = 0.8 kg·m².

step_by_step.explanation: Negative k̂ component means clockwise torque about z-axis
τ = Iα requires net external torque; This is only one torque; Other torques must exist
The given force produces 1.5 N·m torque, but net torque must be 1.6 N·m for given α; Additional torque of 0.1k̂ N·m must act on disk
Given α⃗ = +2k̂ (counterclockwise), but calculated τ⃗ = -1.5k̂ (clockwise); Inconsistency indicates other torques must overcome this and provide net counterclockwise torque
For α = +2 rad/s² and I = 0.8 kg·m²: τ_net = 1.6k̂ N·m counterclockwise

worked_examples.final_answer: Single force produces τ⃗ = -1.5k̂ N·m, but net torque must be τ_net = Iα⃗ = +1.6k̂ N·m for given motion; Additional torque of +3.1k̂ N·m required; τ = Iα applies to net external torque, not individual torques

sections.introduction: Developing systematic approaches for applying τ = Iα to solve rotational dynamics problems, including free-body diagrams, coordinate systems, and multi-step analysis.

key_concept.definition: Problem-solving framework, Free-body diagrams, Coordinate systems, Net torque calculation, Simultaneous equations, Physical interpretation
key_concept.context: Effective application of rotational Newton's second law requires systematic problem-solving strategies including proper diagramming, coordinate system selection, net torque calculation, and physical interpretation of results.

classifications.value: Classification based on systematic approaches to rotational dynamics
classifications.behavior: Different problem-solving methods provide specific advantages: free-body diagrams visualize all forces and torques, coordinate systems establish sign conventions, net torque calculation identifies rotational causes, and physical checks validate solutions

classifications.note: Problem-solving steps: (1) Identify system and axis, (2) Draw free-body diagram, (3) Choose coordinate system, (4) Calculate net torque, (5) Apply τ = Iα, (6) Solve for unknowns, (7) Verify physically

principles.statement: Systematic approaches ensure successful rotational dynamics problem solving: Problem-Solving Framework: Identify rotating system and rotation axis; Draw extended free-body diagram showing all forces; Choose coordinate system and sign convention; Calculate net torque about axis; Apply Στ = Iα; Solve for unknown quantities; Verify physical reasonableness. Free-Body Diagrams: Show all external forces; Indicate points of application; Include reaction forces at supports; Identify forces producing torque. Coordinate Systems: Consistent sign convention essential; Usually: counterclockwise positive; Right-hand rule for 3D problems. Net Torque Calculation: Στ = Σ(rFsinθ); Consider both magnitude and direction; Forces through axis produce zero torque; Perpendicular components most effective. Simultaneous Equations: Often combine Στ = Iα with ΣF = ma; Also with kinematic equations; Solve system of equations. Physical Interpretation: Check if answers make sense; Directions consistent; Magnitudes reasonable; Units correct. Common Applications: Rotating pulleys with masses; Objects rolling down inclines; Physical pendulums; Rotating machinery; Vehicle dynamics; Sports equipment. Special Cases: Constant torque → constant α; Zero net torque → constant ω (or ω=0); Combined translation and rotation → use both F=ma and τ=Iα.
principles.application: Apply systematic problem-solving framework. Create extended free-body diagrams. Calculate net torque correctly. Solve simultaneous equations from dynamics. Interpret physical meaning of results. Apply to diverse rotational systems.
principles.example: Solve pulley system with hanging masses. Analyze object rolling down incline. Calculate acceleration in rotational systems.
principles.analogy: Like a mechanic diagnosing a car problem - they systematically check all components (free-body diagram), measure forces and distances (torque calculation), apply the fundamental rules (τ = Iα), solve for the issue, and verify the solution makes sense, rather than randomly guessing what might be wrong

worked_examples.title: Pulley System with Hanging Masses
worked_examples.problem: A 5 kg mass and 3 kg mass hang on either side of a pulley (I = 0.4 kg·m², R = 0.2 m). Find: (a) angular acceleration of pulley, (b) acceleration of masses, (c) tensions in string.

step_by_step.explanation: Let counterclockwise rotation positive; 5 kg mass accelerates down, 3 kg up
For 5 kg: 5g - T₁ = 5a; For 3 kg: T₂ - 3g = 3a
Στ = Iα; T₁R - T₂R = Iα (T₁ produces CCW torque, T₂ produces CW)
T₁R - T₂R = I(a/R); T₁ - T₂ = Ia/R² = 0.4a/(0.2)² = 0.4a/0.04 = 10a
Heavier mass accelerates down but slower than free fall due to pulley inertia and other mass

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) α = 5.45 rad/s²; (b) a = 1.09 m/s²; (c) T₁ = 43.6 N, T₂ = 32.7 N; Pulley inertia reduces acceleration compared to massless pulley; Tensions differ due to pulley rotation

worked_examples.title: Object Rolling Down Incline
worked_examples.problem: A solid cylinder (I = ½MR²) rolls without slipping down a 25° incline. Find linear acceleration of center of mass.

step_by_step.explanation: Forces: mg down, normal force N perpendicular to incline, friction f up incline
x-axis down incline, y-axis perpendicular to incline
ΣF_x = ma; mg sinθ - f = ma
ΣF_y = 0; N - mg cosθ = 0; N = mg cosθ
Στ = Iα; fR = Iα (friction provides torque)
mg sinθ = Ma + ½Ma = 3⁄2Ma; a = (2/3)g sinθ
f = ½Ma = ½M × (2/3)g sinθ = (1/3)Mg sinθ; Must be ≤ μN = μMg cosθ; So μ ≥ (1/3)tanθ = 0.155 for no slipping
Acceleration is 2/3 of object sliding without friction; Some gravity energy goes into rotation

worked_examples.final_answer: a = (2/3)g sinθ = 2.76 m/s²; Rolling without slipping requires friction; Acceleration less than sliding case due to rotational energy; Result valid for μ ≥ (1/3)tanθ

sections.introduction: Extending rotational dynamics to complex systems including combined translation-rotation, time-dependent torques, and real-world engineering applications.

classifications.value: Classification based on complex applications of rotational dynamics
classifications.behavior: Different advanced systems exhibit complex behaviors: combined motion requires simultaneous solution of F=ma and τ=Iα, time-dependent systems need calculus methods, oscillatory motion involves periodic solutions, and engineering applications combine multiple physical principles

classifications.note: Combined motion: ΣF = ma_cm and Στ = Iα about CM, Time-dependent: τ(t) = Iα(t) = I dω/dt, Energy methods: W = ∫τ dθ = ΔK_rot, Complex systems: multiple equations from different principles

principles.statement: Rotational dynamics extends to complex real-world systems: Combined Translation and Rotation: Use both ΣF = ma_cm and Στ_cm = I_cmα; For rolling without slipping: a_cm = Rα; Total kinetic energy: K = ½mv_cm² + ½I_cmω². Time-Dependent Torques: τ(t) = Iα(t) = I(dω/dt); ω(t) = ω₀ + ∫₀ᵗ α(t) dt = ω₀ + (1/I)∫₀ᵗ τ(t) dt; θ(t) = θ₀ + ∫₀ᵗ ω(t) dt. Energy Methods: Work-energy theorem: W_net = ΔK_rot = ½I(ω_f² - ω_i²); Power: P = τω; Conservation of mechanical energy if conservative forces. Oscillatory Rotational Motion: Torsional pendulum: τ = -κθ; Iα = -κθ; α = - (κ/I)θ; ω = √(κ/I); T = 2π√(I/κ). Non-Rigid Body Dynamics: Changing moment of inertia; Combined with angular momentum conservation; I₁ω₁ = I₂ω₂ if no external torque. Complex Mechanical Systems: Gear systems: τ₁/τ₂ = r₁/r₂ = ω₂/ω₁; Belt drives: v = rω constant; Compound systems with multiple rotating parts. Real-World Engineering: Vehicle dynamics: wheel rotation and translation; Robotics: joint motors and manipulators; Machinery: engines, turbines, generators; Sports: projectile motion with spin. Problem-Solving Strategies: Identify all relevant principles; Set up complete equation systems; Use appropriate mathematical methods; Verify physical reasonableness.

worked_examples.title: Yo-Yo Dynamics Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A yo-yo (modeled as solid cylinder, I = ½MR²) unwinds from string of negligible thickness. Find: (a) linear acceleration, (b) angular acceleration, (c) string tension. Assume no slipping at axle.

step_by_step.explanation: Gravity mg down, tension T up; Center accelerates down, rotates about center
Στ = Iα; TR = Iα (tension provides torque)
For yo-yo, a = Rα (string unwinds without slipping)
Acceleration = 2g/3 ≈ 6.53 m/s² vs g = 9.8 m/s²; Slower due to rotation
ΔPE = mgh = ½Mv² + ½Iω² = ½Mv² + ½(½MR²)(v/R)² = ½Mv² + ¼Mv² = 3⁄4Mv²; v² = (4/3)gh; From kinematics: v² = 2ah = 2(2g/3)h = (4/3)gh ✓
Yo-yo accelerates slower than free fall; 1/3 of weight supported by string; 2/3 causes downward acceleration

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) a = (2/3)g = 6.53 m/s²; (b) α = (2/3)g/R; (c) T = (1/3)Mg; Yo-yo dynamics combine translation and rotation with rolling constraint; Acceleration independent of mass and size

worked_examples.title: Time-Dependent Torque Problem
worked_examples.problem: A flywheel (I = 2.5 kg·m²) starts from rest and experiences torque τ(t) = 10 + 2t N·m for 0 ≤ t ≤ 5 s. Find: (a) angular velocity at t=5 s, (b) angular position at t=5 s.

step_by_step.explanation: ω_avg = (ω₀ + ω_f)/2 = (0 + 30)/2 = 15 rad/s; θ = ω_avg t = 15×5 = 75 rad (close, difference due to nonlinear acceleration)
Flywheel reaches 30 rad/s (about 286 rpm) after 5 seconds, rotating through 10.6 revolutions; Increasing torque causes increasing acceleration

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) ω(5) = 30 rad/s; (b) θ(5) = 66.67 rad = 10.61 rev; Time-dependent torque requires integration of τ = Iα; Calculus methods essential for variable acceleration

common_misconceptions: Thinking τ = Iα applies to individual torques rather than net torque
Confusing moment of inertia with angular momentum
Believing rolling friction always opposes motion
Thinking all points on rotating object have same linear acceleration
Confusing the axis for torque calculation and moment of inertia
Believing τ = Iα works for deformable bodies without modification
Thinking angular acceleration always aligns with torque direction in 3D
real_world_applications: Sports equipment dynamics (golf swings, baseball pitches)
summary: Newton's second law for rotation, Στ = Iα, provides the fundamental equation for analyzing rotational dynamics, establishing that net external torque causes angular acceleration proportional to the torque and inversely proportional to the moment of inertia. This rotational analog of F = ma can be rigorously derived from particle dynamics and applies to rigid bodies undergoing fixed-axis rotation. Effective problem-solving requires systematic approaches including extended free-body diagrams, proper coordinate systems, and careful calculation of net torque. The law extends to complex applications including combined translational-rotational motion (where both F = ma and τ = Iα apply simultaneously), time-dependent systems requiring calculus methods, and real-world engineering systems from vehicle dynamics to robotic control. Through these applications, τ = Iα demonstrates its power as the cornerstone of rotational dynamics, enabling prediction and analysis of rotational motion across diverse physical systems.
